name: Launching Women in Robotics Boston!
description:
Are you a woman working in robotics or aspires to? Do you want to expand your network with students, educators, promoters, and professionals in the field? Or simply to build/debug that robotics project waiting in your garage?
Join us for an open discussion about robotics, enabling the launch of the Boston Chapter of the global Women in Robotics community. Attendees from all backgrounds and experience levels are welcome!


Note: This event is open to non-members as well!

Meeting link:
https://meetingsamer12.webex.com/meetingsamer12/j.php?MTID=mb3c56ffdd29723e43dab80703651cd64
Use the above link to join the event using the password: wirb#1

name: A Coffee Chat with Women in Robotics
description:
Women in Robotics Boston has partnered with Vecna Robotics to host a panel discussion with four women in the field of robotics. We are honored to announce our panelists, who hold both technical and non-technical roles at Boston-based Vecna Robotics. We look forward to your participation!
 
The discussion would cover day-to-day of the lives of these industrious women, going from skills required to work as a robotics developer to managing technology startup. 

PS: This event is open to all!

NOTE: RSVP via Eventbrite link only
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/a-coffee-chat-with-women-in-robotics-registration-109910631658



Meet our panelists: 
Kay Perkinson – Chief of Staff, Vecna Robotics
Kay Perkinson is the Chief of Staff and Interim VP of Advanced Development at Vecna Robotics. She is responsible for organizing and aligning strategic priorities with members of the senior leadership team, designing and facilitating the cross-company processes and communications, and supporting the CEO on strategic initiatives. Kay has held a variety of non-technical roles across various industries, including solar technology, healthcare, and finance. She holds a B.A. in Environmental Sciences from Northwestern University, where she played center midfield on the Division I Varsity Women’s Soccer team. Kay lives with her husband, Jim, an Engineering Manager at Boeing, and children, Ashton (17), Logan (4), Evan (3), and Benjamin (2), at their family home in Winchester, MA. 

Diandra Drago – Director of Human Resources, Vecna Robotics
Diandra Oliveira serves as Director of HR at Vecna Robotics, where she is responsible for implementing and executing internal programs, policies, and initiatives around employee engagement and performance, diversity and inclusion, corporate training, and immigration. She is an SHRM Senior Certified Professional and has completed Veterans at Work and Employing Abilities at Work certificates.  Diandra previously served as Director of Talent Acquisition for both Vecna Robotics and its healthcare IT predecessor, Vecna Technologies, and started her career as a Project Manager. She graduated from MIT’s Sloan School of Management with a B.S. in Management Science and spent 3 years in combined computer science and mechanical engineering program. As an undergraduate, she served as both President of MIT Society of Women Engineers and as a Career Fair Director, where she first met Vecna. Diandra lives in Billerica with her husband, Bruno, and daughters Annalise (4) and Carolina (2).  

Zoe Snape – Product Architect – Enterprise Software, Vecna Robotics
Zoe Snape is the Product Architect for the Enterprise team at Vecna Robotics, supporting client integrations work, and working on scaling up our products and platform. Zoe started out working on the first release of Vecna Robotics's web-based tool used to monitor and administrate robots. From there, she was involved in robotics projects like next-gen VGo, OmniEye, QCArmBot, and more. She grew up in Tacoma, Washington, and got her bachelor's in EECS (6-3 for the MIT crowd) in 2015. Currently, she is in Seattle (working from home for 3 years) with her partner who is currently getting his Ph.D. in Astronomy from UW. In her free time, she loves to bake and go for long walks, work out while watching cartoons, and tend to her pea plants and tomatoes in the balcony.
"It's been really cool over the last three years to watch these robots go from being a couple of franken-bots struggling to navigate around cones in an unused corner of someone else's manufacturing facility to a real fleet of dozens of units doing real work at customer sites, with a real manufacturing division, a real support team, and a real deployments team. I'm excited to see where the next three years takes us!"

Janani Mohan – Robotics Software Engineer, Vecna Robotics
Janani Mohan works as a Robotics Software Engineer at Vecna Robotics. She has a Master's degree in Robotics Engineering specialized in Swarm Robotics from Worcester Polytechnic Institute. She was previously employed as an Embedded Systems Engineer at Bosch India. The world of machines and automation has always inspired her and she enjoys making fun hobby projects. The first robot she made is a human following robot called Vodabot which is like a faithful pet but also helps transport items from different rooms, aimed to help the elderly carry items within their household. She envisions a future in Robotics with her contributions to inventing technologies which makes life easier. Apart from Robotics, she is passionate about learning new skills and spends her free time with her plants.

name: Casual Chat with Women in Robotics
description: Hey everyone, let's catch up and get to know more about our members in the group have been up to. Share our thoughts, ideas, inspirations, work-from-home routines and issues in robotics. This is a casual conversation to know what all cool projects our fellow roboticists are working on, ask questions, and just have some fun. Also, if you have any new questions for us we would love to answer those. Let's talk robotics!

name: Bridging the Gap -  Robotics in Industry and Academia with Daniela Rus and Clara Vu
description:
Women in Robotics Boston has partnered with Vecna Robotics to host a technical discussion on Bridging the Gap - Robotics in Industry and Academia.

We are pleased to announce our speakers, two female pioneers in the field of robotics: MIT Professor, Daniela Rus, Director of the MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL) and professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Clara Vu, Co-founder and CTO Veo Robotics. 

The discussion will include the following topics:

  • Ideologies and challenges of a successful robotics startup/research lab
  • Managing practicality in research
  • Robotics and AI technologies that can potentially grow into industrial/commercial products
  • Major differences in expectations of research and industry on distributed robotics and autonomous mobile robots
  • Next big milestone in automation

Please RSVP here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/bridging-the-gap-robotics-in-industry-and-academia-registration-127045369119
where you will have the opportunity to submit your questions in advance of the discussion.
We look forward to your participation!


Meet our speakers:

Daniela Rus is the Andrew (1956) and Erna Viterbi Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science; Director of the Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL); and Deputy Dean of Research for Schwarzman College of Computing at MIT. Rus’ research interests are in robotics, artificial intelligence, and data science. The focus of her work is developing the science and engineering of autonomy, toward the long-term objective of enabling a future with machines pervasively integrated into the fabric of life, supporting people with cognitive and physical tasks. Her research addresses some of the gaps between where robots are today and the promise of pervasive robots: increasing the ability of machines to reason, learn, and adapt to complex tasks in human-centered environments, developing intuitive interfaces between robots and people, and creating the tools for designing and fabricating new robots quickly and efficiently. The applications of this work are broad and include transportation, manufacturing, agriculture, construction, monitoring the environment, underwater exploration, smart cities, medicine, and in-home tasks such as cooking. Rus serves as the Associate Director of MIT’s Quest for Intelligence Core, and as Director of the Toyota-CSAIL Joint Research Center, whose focus is the advancement of AI research and its applications to intelligent vehicles. She is a member of the Toyota Research Institute advisory board. Rus is a Class of 2002 MacArthur Fellow, a fellow of ACM, AAAI and IEEE, and a member of the National Academy of Engineering and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. She is the recipient of the 2017 Engelberger Robotics Award from the Robotics Industries Association. She is a Mitre Senior Visiting Fellow. She earned her PhD in Computer Science from Cornell University.

Clara Vu has been building autonomous robots for over 20 years. She began her career at iRobot in its early days, where she developed robots for oil well exploration and wrote the programming language behind Roomba. After iRobot’s IPO, she went on to found Harvest Automation, where she led software development for their autonomous agricultural materials handling system. This was the world’s first product that combined fully autonomous mobility and manipulation in an unconstrained environment. Clara connected with Patrick Sobalvarro through Rethink Robots, where she became interested in the challenge of human-robot interaction for manufacturing. As CTO of Veo Robotics, Clara leads the company’s advanced technology development and product roadmap planning to solve fundamental problems in durable goods manufacturing.

name: Bioinspired Robotics - from Research to Technology
description:
Please RSVP for the event at Eventbrite, where you will have the opportunity to submit your questions in advance of the discussion. We look forward to your participation!
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/bioinspired-robotics-from-research-to-technology-registration-130826689149

About this Event
Women in Robotics Boston hosts a technical discussion on 'Bioinspired Robotics - from Research to Technology'.
We are pleased to announce our speakers, two female pioneers in the field of bio-inspired robotics: Oregon State University Dr. Julie A. Adams, Associate Director of Research in the Collaborative Robotics and Intelligent Systems Institute at Oregon State University, and Liane Thompson, Co-founder, and CEO of Aquaai.
The discussion will include the following topics:
  • Ideologies and challenges of a successful robotics startup/research lab
  • Managing practicality in research
  • Difficulties in getting a design potentially grow into industrial/commercial products
  • Types and limits of bio-mimicry
  • Next big milestone in bioinspired robot design


Meet our speakers:
 Dr. Julie A. Adams, Professor, Associate Director of the Collaborative Robotics and Intelligent Systems Institute, Oregon State University. Dr. Adams was the founder of the Human-Machine Teaming Laboratory at Vanderbilt University, prior to moving the laboratory to Oregon State. Adams has worked in the area of human-machine teaming for thirty years. Throughout her career she has focused on human interaction with unmanned systems, but also focused on manned civilian and military aircraft at Honeywell, Inc. and commercial, consumer and industrial systems at the Eastman Kodak Company. Her research, which is grounded in robotics applications for domains such as first response, archaeology, oceanography, the national airspace, and the U.S. military, focuses on distributed artificial intelligence, swarms, robotics and human-machine teaming. Dr. Adams received her M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Computer and Information Sciences from the University of Pennsylvania and her B.S. in Computer Science and B.B.E. in Accounting from Siena College. Dr. Adams’ research efforts have been featured in international news outlets, including National Geographic, Scientific American Podcast, Der Spiegel, and BBC on-line. Dr. Adams spoke at TedX Nashville, received the NSF CAREER Award and was selected for the DARPA Computer Science Study Panel. She is a contributor to the National Academies report on Mainstreaming UUVs into the fleet for the CNO and to an Army BAST requested report on counter measures for UAVs. Dr. Adams is also the Oregon State University primary investigator to the FAA Center of Excellence for Unmanned Aerial Systems Research Alliance for System Safety of UAS through Research Excellence (ASSURE) and a member of the Board on Army Research, Development, Test & Evaluation, System Acquisition and Logistics. 

Liane Thompson is the CEO of Aquaai, a marine robotics company that uses data to improve our understanding of ocean and freshwater health by collecting and delivering real-time visual and environmental data to a web-based dashboard. Thompson's company has grown from a daughter’s idea into a full-fledged production, with a global team and backers including GrowthX, Backstage Capital and Boost VC. Norwegian sustainable salmon producer Kvarøy Fiskeoppdrett, suppliers to Whole Foods, is working with Aquaai's bio-inspired finned robots to monitor fish behavior and conditions at their fish farms. Aquaai has been awarded Top Aquaculture Innovation Award 2019 Fish2.0 Global Forum, an Innovation Norway grant, as well as given a Seal of Excellence by the European Union. Prior to starting her positive impact for a Blue Economy company, Liane was a global reporter and New York Times executive creating innovative content with global audience appeal, including the premier television series of the late Anthony Bourdain, A Cook's Tour. She has spearheaded technical and programming firsts in the media industry earning her three time PrimeTime Emmy nominations. Liane's journey as an entrepreneur includes setting up new businesses in Hungary, Israel, the United States and most recently Norway. Liane earned her Bachelor's degrees in International Relations and in German from CSU,Chico and was a recipient of an academic scholarship to Johannes Gutenberg Universität, Mainz, Germany where she studied European Law. A graduate fellow, Liane holds a Master of Arts degree in Journalism and Public Affairs from American University, Washington, DC. Liane is a TEDx speaker and ocean advocate passionate about providing her children a healthier planet.

name: Finding a job in Robotics: Tales from working professionals
description:
Engineers can join the field of robotics from any background, be it Computer Science, Mechanical, Electronics, or Robotics. But how to filter from those thousands of job profiles for an interdisciplinary position and most importantly, understanding what the company is looking for?!
Join us to hear three women in robotics speak about their experience in building resumes, networking, applications, and the interview process. Bonus: Learn what to expect while searching for a job in the pandemic!

The topics of conversation would be but not limited to:
  • Finding companies that are currently hiring
  • LinkedIn networking and employee referrals
  • Nature of different rounds of interviews 
  • Prepping for live coding & whiteboard design questions
  • Resume and cover letter tips
 Lastly, the participants would get a chance to ask any specific questions they may have.

Note: The information shared in the event is solely based on the speakers' experience and not an absolute guideline on what to do. Nevertheless, each speaker has prepared a cheat sheet based on what has worked for them in the past, which would be shared publicly!


Sign up and make sure to fill the google form with questions you may have on the topic: https://forms.gle/DhXhe7YW2r1AyByk9
(Maximum 100 participants)

See you soon!


About the speakers:
Sanjuksha Nirgude is an Advanced Controls Engineer at Symbotic, working on the development of control software for mobile robots. Before joining Symbotic, she worked as an intern for Waypoint Robotics on mobile robots and at Cere Labs on reinforcement learning. She holds a Master's degree in Robotics Engineering from Worcester Polytechnic Institute, Massachusetts. She also holds a Bachelor's degree in Mechanical Engineering from India where she actively participated in university robotics events. Her journey in robotics started after attending a robotics workshop in high school and she continues to work on fascinating robotics problems and their commercialization. Sanjuksha enjoys painting, meeting new people, and kickboxing.

Dharini Dutia is a Robotics (M.Sc) and Electronics (B.Eng) Engineer, actively looking for an opportunity to learn and contribute to autonomous navigation for mobile robots or drone-based applications. Previously, she has worked as a Robotics Software Engineer, working on robot planning, localization, simulation, and testing, for warehousing and logistics applications at Vecna Robotics. During her Masters at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, she has co-authored a research paper in human-robot interaction and completed her thesis in multi-robot coordination. She believes the true purpose of robotics is to do things beyond human capabilities and has been working towards developing systems that do the same. Currently, she lives in Cambridge, Massachusetts where she explores new places around, reads fiction, enjoys painting, and hiking. She loves food, the smell of new books, time travel, and space exploration.

 
Kajal Gada started her journey in robotics by working on personal projects such as a line follower with an Arduino. She then pursued and graduated with a Masters in Robotics from the University of Maryland in 2017.  With 3 years of collective professional experience at Reality AI, Qualcomm, and Brain Corp, she has mastered digging in core robotics problems at ground zero level. Her goal is to develop algorithms for realizing robot operations in the real world and support women in the workplace to pursue a career of their dreams. In her free time, she likes to read mystery novels and play board games.

Check out her Youtube channel about robotics concepts and her experience as a roboticist: https://www.youtube.com/kajalgada

name: Finding a Job in Robotics: Recruiters' Perspective
description:
From ‘what projects are relevant for a job profile’ to ‘why haven’t I received a response from the company yet’, each robotics graduate goes through this ordeal every year! In an attempt to make the job search process seem a little less daunting, we have invited a panel of recruiters and hiring managers to answer frequently asked questions, share tips, tricks, and break some myths.
Join us to hear these experienced professionals share their views about the interview process, candidate pool, skills in demand, and much more.

The topics of conversation would be but not limited to:
  • Dos and don’ts in resume writing
  • Yearly hiring cycles and identifying the market 
  • Nature of different rounds of interviews 
  • Prepping for live coding & whiteboard design questions
  • Networking and follow-up emails
 Lastly, the participants would get a chance to ask any specific questions they may have.
If you have any questions you would like to be covered in the event, please enter them here: https://forms.gle/1Ek5JnivxMXod2u87 

Note: The information shared in the event is solely based on the speakers' experience and not an absolute guideline on what to do.

This event is open to all members of the Women in Robotics Boston group, sign up on the meetingplace group, and RSVP to this event to get the zoom seminar link! 
(Maximum 100 participants)

See you soon!

Speakers:
  1. Laurie McCloskey, 6 River Systems
    Current Position: Recruiting Manager with 6 River Systems & Lead for our Diversity, Inclusion, and Belonging Program
  2. Emily Barden, People Ops Generalist at Optimus Ride
    Emily Barden is a People Operations Generalist at Optimus Ride, a Boston-based autonomous vehicle company. She supports recruitment across the company and acts as an HRBP to the Field Ops Deployment teams since joining in January of this year. Previously, she was with Boston Human Capital Partners operating as an insourced Talent Acquisition Consultant to a variety of Boston-based tech companies. Since graduating from Nichols College with a BSBA focused in Human Resource Management and Entrepreneurship, Emily has held a passion for candidate experience and emphasis for recruiting excellence and execution in a highly competitive market. 
  3. Jennifer Sharpe, Senior Technical Talent Advisor at iRobot
    Jennifer Sharpe is iRobot’s Senior Talent Acquisition Advisor driving the Talent Acquisition strategy for iRobot’s global R&D teams.  She joined iRobot in January 2021 and was most recently the Senior Talent Acquisition Lead for Viasat, a global satellite communications provider serving the consumer, commercial, government, and department of defense markets.  She brings over 15 years of technical talent acquisition experience and has a strong background in early career, high potential, and leadership talent development and is a strengths finder and co-active coaching enthusiast.  Jennifer has a B.S. degree in Kinesiology and her favorite quote is, “Your career is like running your own business, think about what you need to do to make that successful!”, by Jennifer Sharpe.

name: Casual Chat with Women In Robotics
description:
Hey everyone, it's been a while since we last talked and our community has grown since then. Let's catch up and get to know more about each other, welcome our new members in the group and see what everyone's been up to. Share our thoughts, ideas, inspirations, work-from-home routines and issues in robotics. This is a casual conversation to know what all cool projects our fellow roboticists are working on, ask questions, and just have some fun.  If you are interested in organizing events with amazing women in the field to inspire and encourage more women to join the field of robotics, do join us for our upcoming casual talk.
Let's talk robotics!

name: Career Pathways in Robotics with Women in 6 River Systems
description:
Learn about careers in robotics technology and the skills required to be a good robotics engineer.

Women in Robotics Boston partnered with 6 River Systems to host a panel discussion about career pathways for mechanical engineers, electrical engineers, computer science engineers interested in robotics. Join us to learn more about careers in robotics and the skills you will need to be successful in the robotics industry. The event will include a discussion about the day-to-day lives of industrious women building collaborative, mobile robots driven by cloud-based software.


NOTE: Please RSVP on Eventbrite to confirm your participation and submit your questions in advance of the discussion.
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/career-pathways-in-robotics-with-women-in-6-river-systems-registration-151837878181


 We look forward to your participation!


Meet our panelists:

  • Gillan Hawkes, VP, Product & Analytics: Gillan Hawkes is VP of Product Management and Analytics at 6RS where she is responsible for the product vision and roadmap. In this role, she has earned recognition as a Top Woman in Supply Chain by Supply & Demand Chain Executive and a leader making a mark in robotics by SME (Society of Manufacturing Engineers). Prior to joining 6RS, Gillan worked in Finance and Management Consulting before spending 10+ years building and running eCommerce businesses for large retailers in the US and UK such as Tesco, Home Depot, and Staples. Gillan loves running, biking, doing hot yoga, and being a mom to 2 growing boys. Gillan has a BA from Princeton University and an MBA from the London Business School.
  • Jess Podoloff, Program Manager, Deployment: Jess studied Industrial and Systems Engineering at Georgia Tech before jumping into the supply chain scene in Atlanta as a Software Consultant with Manhattan Associates. She then worked in supply chain implementation at The Home Depot before joining 6RS as a Program Manager. Jess currently leads a team deploying robotic systems driven by our cloud-based software.
  • Diarra Bell, Reliability Support Engineer 
  • Katie Boria, Sr. Software Engineer in Test: Katie joined 6RS in 2020 during the covid pandemic and has been enjoying working with her team remotely. Katie graduated with a degree in Management Information Systems but found a love during her first internship with quality assurance testing. After spending the last 20 years as a Systems\Software QA engineer in the Enterprise Storage Business, she has decided to take on the challenge of robotics and warehousing at 6RS. In her spare time, Katie enjoys spending time at the lake with her 2 children, husband, and English mastiff Penny. 
  • Katie Powers, Software Engineering Manager: Katy joined 6RS in 2017 as a software engineer specializing in robotic navigation, after working at several other robotics companies in the Boston area. She has recently begun leading the localization and mapping team. In her spare time, she goes rock climbing in New Hampshire.
  • Savini Prematilleke, Software Engineer: Savini joined 6RS as a Software Reliability Engineer in 2019 and then started a Software Engineer position earlier this year. Prior to joining, Savini graduated from Duke University with a degree in Mechanical Engineering.
  • Taliza Sanchez, Mechanical Engineer: Taliza joined 6RS the summer of 2019 as a Mechanical Engineering co-op after graduating from Northeastern University. She has since transitioned to full-time and is currently a Mechanical Engineer on the Hardware Team, primarily focusing on accessories.

name: Autonomy in Aviation with GreenSight and Autonodyne
description:
Women in Robotics Boston hosts a technical discussion on the present and the future of autonomous unmanned aerial systems as 'Autonomy in Aviation’ with GreenSight and Autonodyne. Dig deeper into the technologies developed by these Boston-based companies pushing the limits of aerial intelligence. The discussion will range from the challenges faced in developing autonomous software, sensor technology, data collection and analysis, various use-cases, and what the future holds for this industry.


The event is open to everyone from any professional background interested in the field. Please RSVP here OR on Eventbrite to save your spot!

NOTE: Total capacity is 100 participants.


We look forward to your participation!



Meet the speakers:

James Peverill, GreenSight’s CEO/CTO and co-founder, is an expert engineer and technical executive who has focused on electric powered unmanned aerial robotics for over 15 years. He has led a huge variety of innovative development efforts for enterprise and government including DARPA, AFRL and NASA in both PM and PI capacities. Wide ranging ambitious technical efforts ranged from air-to-air UAV docking to autonomous landing of micro air vehicles. James founded GreenSight to focus on solving real world problems using ubiquitous robotics technology. He holds an ScB (’03) in Mechanical Engineering from Brown University and a MS in Electrical Engineering from Boston University.

Latimer Gerle is a Systems Engineer at Greensight with qualifications in both the systems and software fields. As evidenced by her prior positions, ranging from golf caddy to optical technician to her extensive experience in the defense industry, she enjoys learning about new topics and tackling new challenges. Her curriculum vitae includes an M.S. in Data Analytics, a B.S. in Computer Science and an enduring passion for the Classics. In her free time, Latimer's interests include traveling, building miniatures, attending rock concerts, and being terrible at golf.

Laura Aptowitz is the Director of Software Engineering at Autonodyne. She have been with the company since 2018. Prior to her time at Autonodyne she worked as an Information Assurance Engineer at General Dynamics - Mission Systems. Laura received her bachelors of science in computer engineering from Union College.

Shrutika Ruhela graduated from Carnegie Mellon University in 2020 with a degree in Electrical and Computer Engineering and Public Policy, and is now a systems engineer at Autonodyne. In college, Shrutika was president of Women in ECE, volunteered for Camp Kesem, and did research on the risks of IOT technology as part of CMU’s CyLab. In her free time, Shrutika runs the peer mentorship program for the Anaya Tipnis Foundation.

name: Bring Your Own Bots
description:
Women in Robotics Boston presents a Robotics Open Mic . . .
Bring your thesis, ideas, projects, and more with our new event series, Bring Your Own Bots! 
This event is a platform to demo a robot or share your personal project or practice your thesis presentation or course projects, anything related to robotics. Get exposure, recognition, and feedback from our supportive robotics community. 
All projects big or small are welcome, this is your stage to shine! Please email us on womeninroboticsboston@gmail.com to let us know you’ll be presenting.

If you don’t have anything to showcase, do attend to learn from and meet fellow roboticists, show your support and share feedback! Please RSVP on the meetingplace group to get joining information for the Zoom meeting.

name: Technical Talk: Situated Multi-Party Human-Robot Interactions by Dr. Marynel Vázquez
description:
Women in Robotics Boston partnered with the Interactive Machines Group at Yale University led by Dr. Marynel Vázquez to learn more about the fundamental problems in social interactions between robots and multiple people. Join us for a technical talk on fundamental principles and algorithms to enable autonomous perception of human behavior, group social phenomena, and the social context of human-robot interactions.

Dr. Marynel Vázquez is an Assistant Professor in Yale’s Computer Science Department, where she leads the Interactive Machines Group. Her research focuses on advancing multi-party human-robot interaction, both by studying social group phenomena and developing perception and decision making algorithms that enable autonomous robot behavior. Marynel received her bachelor's degree in Computer Engineering from Universidad Simón Bolívar in 2008, and obtained her M.S. and Ph.D. in Robotics from Carnegie Mellon University in 2013 and 2017, respectively. Before joining Yale, Marynel was a collaborator of Disney Research and a Postdoctoral Scholar at the Stanford Vision & Learning Lab.

Interactive Machines Group: https://interactive-machines.com/research.html

name: User-Centered Robot Design with iRobot
description:
When designing robots, it is important to keep the end-user in mind throughout the process. Evaluating the impact of robot design on the ideal user experience has become important as more robotic systems enter our daily lives. Women in Robotics Boston partnered with women in iRobot, featuring Lauren Stern, Design Researcher, and Shipra Arora, UX Designer, to share lessons learned, design principles, and tools for evaluating user perception. In this webinar, learn more about:
  • Ways to center the user in robot design and research
  • Broadening scope for an inclusive user experience
  • Evolution in design as guided by research
  • Development of research tools to evaluate robot designs

The event is open to everyone from any professional background interested in the field. Please register to save your spot and sign up to the Women in Robotics Boston group for future updates!
NOTE: Total capacity is 100 participants.

We look forward to your participation!

Meet your speakers:
Lauren Stern is a Design Researcher at iRobot, where she focuses on research efforts related to robot behavior and interactions specific to the home environment. Prior to her time at iRobot, Lauren's UX work focused on research and design of collaborative analysis tools for government and business agencies. ​When not conducting research, she enjoys reading, dancing, and board games.

Shipra Arora is a User Experience Designer at iRobot, where she focuses her design efforts on new product innovation and robot behaviors. Shipra joined iRobot in 2018 after graduating with a degree in Human-Computer Interaction at Carnegie Mellon. ​Prior to her design life, Shipra was a developer and has a hybrid skill set in UX Design, Research and Software Development. She enjoys working at the intersection of all three disciplines, supporting how people make sense of and interact with their world. In her spare time, you can find her painting, traveling & eating all kinds of food, singing all the pop chart hits (sometimes rapping), and she loves board games too!  ​


Summary
Stories from the research and design of household robots with key takeaways for others on keeping users in mind during robot development.

name: [CANCELED] Off the Clock with Women in Robotics Boston
description:
Unfortunately, we've decided to cancel this event for now. Stay safe!


Finally, let's meet!!!
After functioning virtually since our launch, we're excited to host an in-person event at the MassRobotics office.
Join us for a socially distanced off-the-clock meetup where we can talk robots, interact with enterprising women, or simply get a reason to go out of the house! 

The maximum capacity of the event is 40 people, so please RSVP and if you cannot make it, please cancel your RSVP by emailing us at womeninroboticsboston@gmail.com. If there is a ton of interest, we will make this a recurring event.
RSVP here: https://forms.gle/ZWFoiTfnPGg1Y6yk6

  • Keeping in mind the current situation, we are requesting only vaccinated members to attend (proof of vaccination is required). Also, please wear a face mask at all times inside the building.
  • Please arrive at the location 15 mins prior to the event time to find parking and give enough time to check yourself in. 

Subscribe to the MassRobotics newsletter to stay updated on startup news, robotics events, and much more ... https://massrobotics.us14.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=e49ee727b51b3f8daf7fdee0b&id=24ee87169f

Again don't forget to RSVP by filling the form! See you then :-)
